Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Looking at the system log provided, there are multiple applications involved: Microsoft Word, Google Chrome, Adobe Acrobat, and Microsoft Excel. The user switches between these apps, working on different documents or emails. So each case here likely represents a session where the user completes a specific task involving one of those applications.

Then switches to Chrome to email about Annual Meeting. Replies, types reply with details, saves, sends the email. Then switches again to Acrobat to open Report_Draft.pdf, scrolls, highlights text. Then back to Word for Quarterly_Report.docx to add a reference and save again before closing.

Text: But how do process miners handle such cases? Typically, if an activity (like opening/closing) resets some context, then you start a new instance of the process. But here, closing Document1 might not reset everything; maybe theres another way to group them as one case that spans multiple open/close events. However, in reality, when someone closes and reopens a document later with changes, its often considered part of the same work session if they are revisiting it.
